case_name: Rajwant Singh v. The State of Kerala

facts.text: Criminal Appeals Nos. 102 and 103 of 1965 are appeals by special leave from judgments and orders dated October 12, 1964 of the Kerala High Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeals Nos. 102 103 of 1965. Appeals by special leave from the judgments and orders dated October 12, 1964 of the Kerala High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 80 of 1964, and Criminal Appeal No. 70 and Referred Trial No. 13 of 1964 respectively.

facts.text: Appellants convicted under sections 302/34, 364, 392, 394 and 447 of the Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants in these two appeals have been companyvicted under ss. 302/34, 364, 392, 394 and 447 of the Indian Penal Code. Unni  appellant in this appeal  has been sentenced to death and Rajwant Singh  appellant in the other appeal  has been sentenced to imprisonment for life.

facts.text: Unni sentenced to death.

anchor.surface_text: Unni  appellant in this appeal  has been sentenced to death and Rajwant Singh  appellant in the other appeal  has been sentenced to imprisonment for life. No separate sentences under the other sections have been imposed on Unni but Rajwant Singh has been sentenced to four years rigorous imprisonment under ss. 392 and 394, Indian Penal Code, with a direction that the sentences shall run companycurrently with the sentence of imprisonment for life.

facts.text: Rajwant Singh sentenced to imprisonment for life and four years rigorous imprisonment under ss. 392 and 394 concurrently.

anchor.surface_text: Rajwant Singh  appellant in the other appeal  has been sentenced to imprisonment for life. No separate sentences under the other sections have been imposed on Unni but Rajwant Singh has been sentenced to four years rigorous imprisonment under ss. 392 and 394, Indian Penal Code, with a direction that the sentences shall run companycurrently with the sentence of imprisonment for life.

facts.text: Kerala High Court dismissed appeals and confirmed death sentence on Unni.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Kerala has dismissed their appeals and companyfirmed the sentence of death on Unni. They number appeal by special leave of this Court.

facts.text: Appellants tried with three others; two acquitted, Taylor convicted to life imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: These appellants were tried with three others, of whom two were acquitted. One Taylor was also companyvicted of the same offences and was sentenced in the aggregate to imprisonment for life. He has number appealed to this Court.

facts.text: Lt. Commander Menianha died on the night of March 30, 1963 at Naval Base, I.N.S. Vendurthy, Willingdon Island, Cochin Harbour.

anchor.surface_text: The case relates to the death of one Lt. Commander Menianha of the Naval Base, I.N.S. Vendurthy, Willingdon Island, Cochin Harbour, on the night of March 30, 1963.

facts.text: Unni was attached as a rating to the Naval Base and was on leave at the time of the offence.

anchor.surface_text: Unni was attached as a rating to this Naval Base and at the time of the offence was on leave,. Taylor, who has number appealed was an ex-sailor and Rajwant Singh was attached to I.N.S. Vikrant.

facts.text: Taylor was an ex-sailor.

anchor.surface_text: Taylor, who has number appealed was an ex-sailor and Rajwant Singh was attached to I.N.S. Vikrant.

facts.text: Rajwant Singh was attached to I.N.S. Vikrant.

anchor.surface_text: Rajwant Singh was attached to I.N.S. Vikrant. The case of the prosecution was that these persons companyspired together to burgle the safe of the Base Supply Office on the eve of the pay-day, when a large sum of money was usually kept there for distribution on the pay-day.

facts.text: Accused conspired to burgle the safe of the Base Supply Office on eve of pay-day.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the prosecution was that these persons companyspired together to burgle the safe of the Base Supply Office on the eve of the pay-day, when a large sum of money was usually kept there for distribution on the pay-day. They companylected various articles such as a Naval Officers dress, a bottle of chloroform, a hacksaw with spare blades, adhesive plaster, companyton wool and ropes.

facts.text: Accused collected Naval Officers dress, bottle of chloroform, hacksaw with spare blades, adhesive plaster, cotton wool and ropes.

anchor.surface_text: They companylected various articles such as a Naval Officers dress, a bottle of chloroform, a hacksaw with spare blades, adhesive plaster, companyton wool and ropes. On the night in question they decoyed the Lt. Commander from his house on the pretext that he was wanted at the Naval Base, and in a lonely place caught hold of him.

facts.text: Accused decoyed Lt. Commander from his house on pretext he was wanted at Naval Base.

anchor.surface_text: On the night in question they decoyed the Lt. Commander from his house on the pretext that he was wanted at the Naval Base, and in a lonely place caught hold of him.

facts.text: In lonely place, accused sealed victim's mouth with adhesive plaster, tied handkerchief over it, plugged nostrils with cotton wool soaked in chloroform.

anchor.surface_text: They companyered his mouth with the adhesive plaster and tied a handkerchief over the plaster and plugged his numbertrils with companyton wool soaked in chloroform. They tied his hands and legs with rope and deposited him in a shallow drain with his own shirt put under his head as a pillow.

facts.text: Accused tied victim's hands and legs with rope and deposited him in shallow drain with his shirt under head.

anchor.surface_text: They tied his hands and legs with rope and deposited him in a shallow drain with his own shirt put under his head as a pillow. They then went up to the sentry, who was induced to part with his rifle to one of the accused who had dressed himself as an officer, and attacked him.

facts.text: One accused dressed as officer induced sentry to part with rifle and attacked him; sentry raised hue and cry, attracting watchman; assailants released sentry and fled.

anchor.surface_text: They then went up to the sentry, who was induced to part with his rifle to one of the accused who had dressed himself as an officer, and attacked him. The sentry would have received the same treatment as his Lt. Commander but he raised a hue and cry and attracted the attention of the watchman. Fearing detection the assailants released the sentry and took to their heels.

facts.text: Sentry recognized Rajwant Singh as one of assailants and informed Officer-on-duty.

anchor.surface_text: The sentry after escaping informed the Officer-on-duty at the Base and stated that he had recognised Rajwant Singh as one of his assailants. Next morning the dead body of the Lt. Commander was discovered in the drain where he had been left by the assailants.

facts.text: Next morning, dead body of Lt. Commander discovered in the drain.

anchor.surface_text: Next morning the dead body of the Lt. Commander was discovered in the drain where he had been left by the assailants. Investigation followed and five persons were placed on trial before the Session Judge, Ernakulam Division, who companyvicted three and sentenced them as stated above and acquitted the other two.

facts.text: Five persons tried before Sessions Judge, Ernakulam Division; three convicted, two acquitted.

anchor.surface_text: Investigation followed and five persons were placed on trial before the Session Judge, Ernakulam Division, who companyvicted three and sentenced them as stated above and acquitted the other two. The appeals of these persons before the High Court failed.

facts.text: From inquest and postmortem reports: victim's legs tied with rope, arms tied behind back, large adhesive plaster over mouth sealing it, handkerchief tied over, nostrils plugged with cotton soaked in chloroform.

anchor.surface_text: Our attention has been drawn to the inquest and postmortem reports to establish what was actually done to the Lt. Commander. From these, it is established that the legs of the victim were tied with rope and his arms were tied behind his back. A large adhesive plaster was stuck over his mouth and companypletely sealed it.

facts.text: Death due to asphyxiation.

anchor.surface_text: According to the doctor death was due to asphyxiation.

facts.text: Rajwant Singh made confession before Sub-Magistrate, Cochin describing his and Unni's role.

anchor.surface_text: In addition to the other evidence establishing the companynection of Unni and Rajwant Singh with this crime there is a companyfession by Rajwant Singh before the Sub-Magistrate, Cochin in which he graphically describes the part played by him and Unni.

facts.text: Appellants contend offence not murder but culpable homicide not amounting to murder.

anchor.surface_text: In these appeals the companyplicity of the appellants in the offence is number challenged but it is argued that the evidence for the prosecution does number establish the offence of murder but of causing grievous hurt or of culpable homicide number amounting to murder.

facts.text: Court holds offence is murder under section 302/34 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that the offence was murder. All the acts were done after deliberation by the appellants.

facts.text: Death caused by acts sufficient in ordinary course of nature under clause 3 of s.300 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The bodily injury companysisted of tying up the hands and feet of the victim, closing the mouth with adhesive plaster and plugging the numbertrils with companyton soaked in chloroform. All these acts were deliberate acts which had been preplanned and they, therefore, satisfy the subjective test involved in the clause.

facts.text: Unni was the master mind behind the affair.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the sentence of death passed on Unni, we see numberreason to interfere. He was the master mind behind the whole affair and the sentence of death was, therefore, appropriate.

arguments.claim: first clause of s.300 does not apply as no intention to cause death

anchor.surface_text: But it is plain that the appellants did number contemplate killing the Lt. Commander. No part of their preparations shows an intention to kill.

arguments.claim: second clause of s.300 does not apply as no subjective knowledge that intended injury likely to cause death

anchor.surface_text: Can it be said that they had the subjective knowledge of the fatal consequences of the bodily harm they were causing? We think that on the facts the answer cannot be in the affirmative.

arguments.claim: acts fall under third clause of s.300: intentional bodily injury sufficient in ordinary course of nature to cause death

anchor.surface_text: The third clause discards the test of subjective knowledge. It deals with acts done with the intention of causing bodily injury to a person and the bodily injury intended to be inflicted is sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause death.

arguments.claim: Virsa Singh test satisfied: injury caused, objectively sufficient to cause death, intention to inflict that injury

anchor.surface_text: As was laid down in Virsa Singh v. The State of Punjab 1 for the application of this clause it must be first established that an injury is caused, next it must be established objectively what the nature of that injury in the ordinary course of nature is.

arguments.claim: common intention under s.34; all responsible for murder as acts done with shared intention after deliberation

anchor.surface_text: That there was a common intention admits of no doubt and as clause 3 of s. 300 views the consequence of the act objectively all those who shared the common intention of causing the bodily injury which was sufficient to cause death
We accordingly hold that the offence was murder. All the acts were done after deliberation by the appellants.

arguments.claim: death sentence on Unni appropriate as he was master mind

anchor.surface_text: As regards the sentence of death passed on Unni, we see no reason to interfere. He was the master mind behind the whole affair and the sentence of death was, therefore, appropriate.

arguments.claim: acts also imminently dangerous under fourth clause of s.300

anchor.surface_text: To tie a man so that he cannot help himself, to close his mouth completely and plug his nostrils with cotton wool soaked in chloroform is an act imminently dangerous to life, and it may well be said to satisfy the requirements of the last clause also

holdings.text: the first clause of s. 300 cannot apply

anchor.surface_text: But it is plain that the appellants did not contemplate killing the Lt. Commander. No part of their preparations shows an intention to kill. Had they so desired, they had ample time and opportunity to effectuate that purpose without going to the trouble of using cotton soaked in chloroform to stuff the nostrils. They had only to hold his nose closed for a few minutes. The confession to which we have referred also shows that the news of the death of the Lt. Commander came to them with as much surprise as shock. In these circumstances, the first clause of s. 300 cannot apply.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No preparation or evidence shows intention to kill; confession indicates surprise at death.

holdings.text: Can it be said that they had the subjective knowledge of the fatal consequences of the bodily harm they were causing? We think that on the facts the answer cannot be in the affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: Can it be said that they had the subjective knowledge of the fatal consequences of the bodily harm they were causing? We think that on the facts the answer cannot be in the affirmative. To say that the act satisfied the test of subjective knowledge would be really tantamount to saying that the appellants intended to commit the murder of the Lt. Commander which, as said already, was not the case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No subjective foresight of death beyond rendering unconscious; would equate to intention to murder which is absent.

holdings.text: the acts of the appellants were covered by the third clause in s. 300

anchor.surface_text: In this case the acts of the appellants were covered by the third clause in s. 300. As we are satisfied that this case falls within clause thirdly we need hardly consider whether it falls also within the fourth clause or not.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Virsa Singh test satisfied: deliberate pre-planned injuries (tying, sealing mouth, plugging nostrils with chloroform-soaked cotton) objectively sufficient in ordinary course to cause death by asphyxiation; no intervening cause.

holdings.text: To tie a man so that he cannot help himself, to close his mouth completely and plug his nostrils with cotton wool soaked in chloroform is an act imminently dangerous to life, and it may well be said to satisfy the requirements of the last clause also

anchor.surface_text: To tie a man so that he cannot help himself, to close his mouth completely and plug his nostrils with cotton wool soaked in chloroform is an act imminently dangerous to life, and it may well be said to satisfy the requirements of the last clause also, although that clause is ordinarily applicable to cases in which there is no intention to kill any one in particular.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Acts imminently dangerous likely to cause death, but unnecessary to decide as third clause applies.

holdings.text: We accordingly hold that the offence was murder

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that the offence was murder. All the acts were done after deliberation by the appellants. They were of a type which required more than one person to perpetrate. What was done had already been discussed and the execution of the plan was carried out as contemplated.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deliberate pre-planned acts satisfy third clause of s.300 objectively; culpability upgraded from culpable homicide to murder.

holdings.text: the appellants were rightly adjudged guilty under s. 302/34, Indian Penal Code

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment the appellants were rightly adjudged guilty under s. 302/34, Indian Penal Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Murder established under s.300 thirdly; complicity accepted, rightly convicted by lower courts.

holdings.text: That there was a common intention admits of no doubt and as clause 3 of s. 300 views the consequence of the act objectively all those who shared the common intention [...] must be held responsible for the resulting offence

anchor.surface_text: That there was a common intention admits of no doubt and as clause 3 of s. 300 views the consequence of the act objectively all those who shared the common intention of causing the bodily injury which was sufficient to cause death in the ordinary course of nature must be held responsible for the resulting offence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pre-planned joint acts with deliberation establish shared intention; s.34 makes all liable for murder result viewed objectively.

holdings.text: As regards the sentence of death passed on Unni, we see no reason to interfere. He was the master mind behind the whole affair and the sentence of death was, therefore, appropriate

anchor.surface_text: As regards the sentence of death passed on Unni, we see no reason to interfere. He was the master mind behind the whole affair and the sentence of death was, therefore, appropriate. We see no force in either appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unni mastermind warrants death; distinguishable role from co-accused.

precedents.citation: Virsa Singh v. The State of Punjab 1

anchor.surface_text: As was laid down in Virsa Singh v. The State of Punjab 1  for the application of this clause it must be first established that an injury is caused, next it must be established objectively what the nature of that injury in the ordinary course of nature is. If the injury is found to be sufficient to cause death one test is satisfied.

precedents.case_name: Virsa Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: For application of third clause of s. 300 IPC: (1) injury must be established, (2) its nature objectively sufficient in ordinary course of nature to cause death, (3) intention to inflict that particular injury which is not accidental.
precedents.cited_holding: If the injury is found to be sufficient to cause death one test is satisfied. Then it must be proved that there was an intention to inflict that very injury and not some other injury and that it was not accidental or unintentional. If this is also held against the offender the offence of murder is established.

anchor.surface_text: As was pointed out in Anda v. State of Rajasthan 1  the emphasis in clause thirdly is on the sufficiency of the injury in the ordinary course of nature to cause death. The sufficiency is the high probability of death in the ordinary way of nature and when this exists and death ensues, and if the causing of the injury is intended, the offence is murder.

precedents.cited_proposition: Emphasis in clause thirdly of s. 300 is on sufficiency of injury in ordinary course of nature to cause death; sufficiency means high probability of death from such injury when intended and death ensues.
precedents.cited_holding: the emphasis in clause thirdly is on the sufficiency of the injury in the ordinary course of nature to cause death. The sufficiency is the high probability of death in the ordinary way of nature and when this exists and death ensues, and if the causing of the injury is intended, the offence is murder.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment the appellants were rightly adjudged guilty under s. 302/34, Indian Penal Code. As regards the sentence of death passed on Unni, we see numberreason to interfere. He was the master mind behind the whole affair and the sentence of death was, therefore, appropriate.

outcome.relief_summary: Appellants rightly adjudged guilty under s. 302/34 IPC; no reason to interfere with death sentence on Unni as he was the mastermind; no force in either appeal

anchor.surface_text: But it is plain that the appellants did not contemplate killing the Lt. Commander. No part of their preparations shows an intention to kill. Had they so desired, they had ample time and opportunity to effectuate that purpose without going to the trouble of using cotton soaked in chloroform to stuff the nostrils. They had only to hold his nose closed for a few minutes. The confession to which we have referred also shows that the news of the death of the Lt. Commander came to them with as much surprise as shock. In these circumstances, the first clause of s. 300 cannot apply.

In our judgment the appellants were rightly adjudged guilty under s. 302/34, Indian Penal Code. As regards the sentence of death passed on Unni, we see numberreason to interfere. He was the master mind behind the whole affair and the sentence of death was, therefore, appropriate.

anchor.surface_text: Can it be said that they had the subjective knowledge of the fatal consequences of the bodily harm they were causing? We think that on the facts the answer cannot be in the affirmative. To say that the act satisfied the test of subjective knowledge would be really tantamount to saying that the appellants intended to commit the murder of the Lt. Commander which, as said already, was not the case.

In our judgment the appellants were rightly adjudged guilty under s. 302/34, Indian Penal Code. As regards the sentence of death passed on Unni, we see numberreason to interfere. He was the master mind behind the whole affair and the sentence of death was, therefore, appropriate.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that the offence was murder. All the acts were done after deliberation by the appellants. They were of a type which required more than one person to perpetrate. What was done had already been discussed and the execution of the plan was carried out as contemplated.
